Symptoms of Airborne Allergies and Asthma
Disclaimer:The advice provided in this application is strictly only for informational purposes. Always seek a medical professional\'s advise to alleviate severe pollen allergy or asthma symptoms
Our vision is to help build resilience among our communities in Victoria that are adapting to the health impacts of climate change.

Rhinitis or Hay Fever is one of the most prevalent allergic diseases in Australia which affects almost 15% of its population.This can be caused due to dust particles, pollen, air pollutants, animal fur etc. The alarming rate, at which climate change has increased, has caused Earth’s temperature to rise which has a direct effect on air quality.Elevated levels of greenhouse gases have tampered flowering seasons, pollen production and pollen dispersion. Researchers estimate that pollen counts are going to double by the 2040 and allergies are going to get way worse.In Australia, Canberra and Melbourne face high rates of asthma, rhinitis and various other allergic diseases which make them the most vulnerable to climate changes.

Our proposed application ‘Polemy’ provides users with an understanding of how current weather can elevate pollen allergy, asthma and other respiratory disease symptoms. It also provides users with information about pollen spewing plants in their vicinity further helping them avoid such regions or to take caution. Our application also helps users understand the simple preventive measures that can be applied to manage allergic or asthmatic symptoms. Polemy is developed to help a target audience between the ages 25 to 50 years help manage airborne allergies as a result of climate change.
Monitoring public announcements of air quality and by remaining indoors during high pollution episodes.
Levels of air pollution in the home can be reduced by adequate ventilation.
Carry your inhalation device such as the press-and-breathe pressurised metered dose inhaler (MDI).
Engage in activities that protect and promote health; ex: participate in a regular exercise program.
Monitor and manage symptoms and signs of illness; ex: monitor shortness of breath or sputum colour, visit a physician sooner rather than later.
Click here to view to view various symptoms of airborne allergies and asthma along with simple preventive measure.
Very Cold!!!\n Stay Indoors, Stay Warm
Cool…\n Cover yourself when going out
Mild :)\n Lovely weather to go outside
Hot!\n Sunscreen Please and Drink lots of Water
Very Good\n No Health Impacts. Enjoy your day!
Good\n Traces of particulate matter might cause discomfort for extremely sensitive people.
Fair\n Carry Inhaler/Medication, Limit Physical Activities
Poor\n Carry Inhaler/Medication, Limit Physical Activities to Early Hours of the Day
Very Poor\n Do not Exercise. Follow Asthma Action Plan
High\n Cover nose and mouth. Carry prescribed medications. Try to avoid going out.
Humid\n Carry Inhaler/Medication, Minimal Exercise Please!
Too Humid!!\n Stay Indoors. Do not Exercise and follow your \'Asthma Action Plan\'.
Calm\n No Health Impacts. Be cautious of smoke!
Gentle Breeze\n Leaves and small twigs in constant motion. Moderate Pollen.
Moderate Wind\n More pollen and dust in the air. Cover nose and mouth.
Fresh Wind\n High pollen and particulate matter. Cover nose and mouth.
